text:
Hi all, I've been wanting to do a blog as a side project (hopefully can add to my freelancer site) and was wondering if you have any suggestions of where to host?

My main goal is to put my writing out there and hopefully be somewhere people can find it. So was debating doing a medium but please let me know if you have any suggestions!

I wanted to blog about start-ups, tech, and how work is changing

text:
Hi Georgette,

Are you looking to test the waters or are you sold on the idea of blogging?

Are you wanting to monetize it one day/right away?

In my opinion the costs of hosting a wordpress site are so cheap it makes blogging such a low barrier-to-entry business that I would recommend you just start there.

Plus if you're in this group you already have a leg up on a lot of bloggers and could probably get some traction a little bit earlier. I think a lot of people lean to medium for the opportunity to reach a wider audience from the get go.

text:
Hey <@UNJTESWCW> from what you’ve just said, I think Medium would be a good way to go.

It comes at no cost for you.
You will be able to share your posts in a portfolio easier.
And you get to harness the audience already on Medium to see your content.

text: <@UNJTESWCW> from personal experience tech is a very small niche of blogs out there. As someone who runs two of them in that category, I still don't have as much traction as I would like to with them. I would say <http://medium.com|medium.com> would be better to start and I wish I would have gone that route versus buying and hosting websites. If I didn't have a definitive brand with the one I would sell it.

text: Best practice to not get steamrolled is to publish on your own domain (however is easiest for you) and then import to Medium - <https://sendcheckit.com/blog/why-you-should-put-your-content-on-medium-and-your-own-domain>

attachments.fallback: Why You Should Put Your Content on Both Medium and Your Own Domain
attachments.text: How to leverage your own site and Medium without duplicate content issues.
attachments.title: Why You Should Put Your Content on Both Medium and Your Own Domain

text:
*Long story short: My position responsibilities have exploded due to my company's unrealistic idea of what 'content' is — is it off-base to ask for a raise?*

I was hired as a "content specialist" by a medium-sized enterprise and expected to do two things: write content driven by keyword research and tweak landing page copy. Because this was their focus during hiring I (naively) assumed the more foundational essentials of content marketing were well-established.  For 58K, I felt those were relatively low-stress responsibilities for an okay salary that left a lot of time for freelancing.

However, once I brought these more severe issues to their attention, they were added to my responsibilities. I am now editing and auditing each piece of (old and new) content, supervising 3 external writers, building and designing an actual content marketing funnel, creating a visual and editorial brand style guide, correcting poor web taxonomy, doing web UX design for the knowledge base and then building/coding it out, producing internal and external video content, and training someone else to do video and animation design... all while trying to copyedit the awful copy in our client whitepapers and writing customer support content. Not to mention email copy and other internal document copy. There are no SOPs for anything; I'm writing them all.

I realize I brought this upon myself by not doing my due diligence, and also because I hate doing 'average' quality work... but *is it too late to ask for a raise 6 months in? How do I approach that conversation?* It feels like I am doing the work of five people and I am very tired. Or maybe I'm just complaining? I'd love a temperature check from you all.

elements.text: Long story short: My position responsibilities have exploded due to my company's unrealistic idea of what 'content' is — is it off-base to ask for a raise?

I was hired as a "content specialist" by a medium-sized enterprise and expected to do two things: write content driven by keyword research and tweak landing page copy. Because this was their focus during hiring I (naively) assumed the more foundational essentials of content marketing were well-established.  For 58K, I felt those were relatively low-stress responsibilities for an okay salary that left a lot of time for freelancing.

However, once I brought these more severe issues to their attention, they were added to my responsibilities. I am now editing and auditing each piece of (old and new) content, supervising 3 external writers, building and designing an actual content marketing funnel, creating a visual and editorial brand style guide, correcting poor web taxonomy, doing web UX design for the knowledge base and then building/coding it out, producing internal and external video content, and training someone else to do video and animation design... all while trying to copyedit the awful copy in our client whitepapers and writing customer support content. Not to mention email copy and other internal document copy. There are no SOPs for anything; I'm writing them all.

I realize I brought this upon myself by not doing my due diligence, and also because I hate doing 'average' quality work... but
is it too late to ask for a raise 6 months in? How do I approach that conversation?
It feels like I am doing the work of five people and I am very tired. Or maybe I'm just complaining? I'd love a temperature check from you all.

text: I recommend documenting the additional responsibilities so your management and leadership can see, in black and white, how dramatically the scope of your role has changed. If you can, figure out what that role really is…at a minimum, I think that sounds like it’s now a Content Marketing Manager or Content Lead role. With that, you can show them how much you’re underpaid. IMHO if they’re not willing to give you a raise immediately, they should have a clear timeline for when you’ll get a raise and title promotion (i.e., next performance review period).

elements.text: I recommend documenting the additional responsibilities so your management and leadership can see, in black and white, how dramatically the scope of your role has changed. text: If you were working at a brand new startup, I might say, that’s how it goes. But a medium-sized enterprise is different. You’re doing mid-level work for an entry-level salary.

elements.text: If you were working at a brand new startup, I might say, that’s how it goes. But a medium-sized enterprise is different. You’re doing mid-level work for an entry-level salary.

Agree with Cassandra! You are definitely doing more and you are not complaining. Show the difference and if possible share some of the tangible benefits the company has gotten from your efforts like better rankings, more demo requests, etc. Showing the benefits will make it easier to request a raise.

elements.text: Agree with Cassandra! You are definitely doing more and you are not complaining. Show the difference and if possible share some of the tangible benefits the company has gotten from your efforts like better rankings, more demo requests, etc. Showing the benefits will make it easier to request a raise.

text: Sounds like you really know your stuff. They're not going to fire you if you ask for a raise. And even if they do, you put all that on your resume and you'll have a new job in no time.

elements.text: Sounds like you really know your stuff. They're not going to fire you if you ask for a raise. And even if they do, you put all that on your resume and you'll have a new job in no time.

text: <@U031JEFLBC3> there is a massive disconnect between your title and your responsibilities. The only thing I'd add to the (excellent) advice that <@U01J85VRKF1> and <@URAV154AV> offered is that many times executives and non marketing folks don't have a clear idea of what the roles are supposed to look like and what those responsibilities and compensation levels are. I've found it really useful to provide examples of structure and salaries at other companies that the executive team holds up as aspirational. If you pair that together with a plan + outcomes and they _don't_ give you a title + payraise then you probably need to start looking for a new role.

text: Hello all! Does anyone have any tips on nailing a discovery call?

elements.text: Hello all! Does anyone have any tips on nailing a discovery call?

text:
Some great advice in this thread here.

Even if you don't have the required results yet, it could also be an interviewing and framing thing. Make sure you're continually speaking about how you want to connect content to measurable business results & how you would do that. This could be through SEO, through lead gen, through thought leadership as measured by brand awareness data or survey recall.

Don't just be a content for content's sake person.

elements.text:

text:
Hey <@U03330MFEN4> :wave::skin-tone-2: I do them all day every day with our new prospects, so have some experience here...

By far the biggest thing that's helped me is to move my mindset into being a trusted advisor more than a salesperson. As I've grown my industry knowledge it really helps to be able to offer insider suggestions and shortcuts to anyone thinking of working together. It might seem counterintuitive to give away knowledge before someone buys, but it actually works to dramatically build the trust and buy-in on their side. Often almost a whole call will go past without me offering anything in terms of solutions, and that makes for a much better experience on both sides.

Also, one resource I'd really recommend is checking out Neil Rackham's SPIN selling as it totally flips the burden/awkwardness of selling on it's head.

Hope that helps! :pray::skin-tone-2:

Often almost a whole call will go past without me offering anything in terms of solutions, and that makes for a much better experience on both sides.

Also, one resource I'd really recommend is checking out Neil Rackham's SPIN selling as it totally flips the burden/awkwardness of selling on it's head.

Hope that helps!

text:
It sounds like you're doing director level work. That would be a considerable pay bump, and likely a tough pill for them to swallow all at once. That said, if you're digging the company, it would be wise to propose an accelerated salary growth plan that aligns with milestones and targets. 

This doesn't just include traffic and lead goals, but also hiring goals, because you could end up in a position of doing a bunch of things, but none of them as well as they could.

If you're not so jazzed about the company, then consider it a resume builder. At the level of work you're doing, it's easily a $150-$175k position if the output is awesome and drives results.
